<ProgramListing>

<Link id="l00001" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//===-- AMDGPULowerModuleLDSPass.cpp ------------------------------&#42;- C++ -&#42;-=//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00002" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00003" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Part of the LLVM Project, under the Apache License v2.0 with LLVM Exceptions.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00004" /><CodeLine lineNumber="4"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// See https://llvm.org/LICENSE.txt for license information.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00005" /><CodeLine lineNumber="5"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// SPDX-License-Identifier: Apache-2.0 WITH LLVM-exception</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00006" /><CodeLine lineNumber="6"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00007" /><CodeLine lineNumber="7"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//===----------------------------------------------------------------------===//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00008" /><CodeLine lineNumber="8"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00009" /><CodeLine lineNumber="9"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// This pass eliminates local data store, LDS, uses from non-kernel functions.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00010" /><CodeLine lineNumber="10"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// LDS is contiguous memory allocated per kernel execution.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00011" /><CodeLine lineNumber="11"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00012" /><CodeLine lineNumber="12"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Background.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00013" /><CodeLine lineNumber="13"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00014" /><CodeLine lineNumber="14"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// The programming model is global variables, or equivalently function local</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00015" /><CodeLine lineNumber="15"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// static variables, accessible from kernels or other functions. For uses from</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00016" /><CodeLine lineNumber="16"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// kernels this is straightforward - assign an integer to the kernel for the</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00017" /><CodeLine lineNumber="17"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// memory required by all the variables combined, allocate them within that.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00018" /><CodeLine lineNumber="18"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// For uses from functions there are performance tradeoffs to choose between.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00019" /><CodeLine lineNumber="19"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00020" /><CodeLine lineNumber="20"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// This model means the GPU runtime can specify the amount of memory allocated.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00021" /><CodeLine lineNumber="21"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// If this is more than the kernel assumed, the excess can be made available</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00022" /><CodeLine lineNumber="22"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// using a language specific feature, which IR represents as a variable with</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00023" /><CodeLine lineNumber="23"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// no initializer. This feature is referred to here as &quot;Dynamic LDS&quot; and is</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00024" /><CodeLine lineNumber="24"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// lowered slightly differently to the normal case.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00025" /><CodeLine lineNumber="25"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00026" /><CodeLine lineNumber="26"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Consequences of this GPU feature:</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00027" /><CodeLine lineNumber="27"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// - memory is limited and exceeding it halts compilation</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00028" /><CodeLine lineNumber="28"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// - a global accessed by one kernel exists independent of other kernels</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00029" /><CodeLine lineNumber="29"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// - a global exists independent of simultaneous execution of the same kernel</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00030" /><CodeLine lineNumber="30"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// - the address of the global may be different from different kernels as they</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00031" /><CodeLine lineNumber="31"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//   do not alias, which permits only allocating variables they use</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00032" /><CodeLine lineNumber="32"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// - if the address is allowed to differ, functions need help to find it</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00033" /><CodeLine lineNumber="33"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00034" /><CodeLine lineNumber="34"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Uses from kernels are implemented here by grouping them in a per-kernel</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00035" /><CodeLine lineNumber="35"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// struct instance. This duplicates the variables, accurately modelling their</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00036" /><CodeLine lineNumber="36"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// aliasing properties relative to a single global representation. It also</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00037" /><CodeLine lineNumber="37"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// permits control over alignment via padding.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00038" /><CodeLine lineNumber="38"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00039" /><CodeLine lineNumber="39"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Uses from functions are more complicated and the primary purpose of this</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00040" /><CodeLine lineNumber="40"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// IR pass. Several different lowering are chosen between to meet requirements</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00041" /><CodeLine lineNumber="41"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// to avoid allocating any LDS where it is not necessary, as that impacts</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00042" /><CodeLine lineNumber="42"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// occupancy and may fail the compilation, while not imposing overhead on a</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00043" /><CodeLine lineNumber="43"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// feature whose primary advantage over global memory is performance. The basic</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00044" /><CodeLine lineNumber="44"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// design goal is to avoid one kernel imposing overhead on another.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00045" /><CodeLine lineNumber="45"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00046" /><CodeLine lineNumber="46"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Implementation.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00047" /><CodeLine lineNumber="47"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00048" /><CodeLine lineNumber="48"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// LDS variables with constant annotation or non-undef initializer are passed</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00049" /><CodeLine lineNumber="49"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// through unchanged for simplification or error diagnostics in later passes.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00050" /><CodeLine lineNumber="50"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Non-undef initializers are not yet implemented for LDS.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00051" /><CodeLine lineNumber="51"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00052" /><CodeLine lineNumber="52"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// LDS variables that are always allocated at the same address can be found</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00053" /><CodeLine lineNumber="53"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// by lookup at that address. Otherwise runtime information/cost is required.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00054" /><CodeLine lineNumber="54"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00055" /><CodeLine lineNumber="55"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// The simplest strategy possible is to group all LDS variables in a single</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00056" /><CodeLine lineNumber="56"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// struct and allocate that struct in every kernel such that the original</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00057" /><CodeLine lineNumber="57"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// variables are always at the same address. LDS is however a limited resource</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00058" /><CodeLine lineNumber="58"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// so this strategy is unusable in practice. It is not implemented here.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00059" /><CodeLine lineNumber="59"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00060" /><CodeLine lineNumber="60"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Strategy | Precise allocation | Zero runtime cost | General purpose |</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00061" /><CodeLine lineNumber="61"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//  --------+--------------------+-------------------+-----------------+</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00062" /><CodeLine lineNumber="62"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//   Module |                 No |               Yes |             Yes |</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00063" /><CodeLine lineNumber="63"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//    Table |                Yes |                No |             Yes |</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00064" /><CodeLine lineNumber="64"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//   Kernel |                Yes |               Yes |              No |</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00065" /><CodeLine lineNumber="65"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//   Hybrid |                Yes |           Partial |             Yes |</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00066" /><CodeLine lineNumber="66"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00067" /><CodeLine lineNumber="67"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// &quot;Module&quot; spends LDS memory to save cycles. &quot;Table&quot; spends cycles and global</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00068" /><CodeLine lineNumber="68"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// memory to save LDS. &quot;Kernel&quot; is as fast as kernel allocation but only works</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00069" /><CodeLine lineNumber="69"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// for variables that are known reachable from a single kernel. &quot;Hybrid&quot; picks</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00070" /><CodeLine lineNumber="70"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// between all three. When forced to choose between LDS and cycles we minimise</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00071" /><CodeLine lineNumber="71"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// LDS use.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00072" /><CodeLine lineNumber="72"></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00073" /><CodeLine lineNumber="73"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// The &quot;module&quot; lowering implemented here finds LDS variables which are used by</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00074" /><CodeLine lineNumber="74"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// non-kernel functions and creates a new struct with a field for each of those</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00075" /><CodeLine lineNumber="75"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// LDS variables. Variables that are only used from kernels are excluded.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00076" /><CodeLine lineNumber="76"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00077" /><CodeLine lineNumber="77"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// The &quot;table&quot; lowering implemented here has three components.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00078" /><CodeLine lineNumber="78"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// First kernels are assigned a unique integer identifier which is available in</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00079" /><CodeLine lineNumber="79"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// functions it calls through the intrinsic amdgcn&#95;lds&#95;kernel&#95;id. The integer</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00080" /><CodeLine lineNumber="80"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// is passed through a specific SGPR, thus works with indirect calls.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00081" /><CodeLine lineNumber="81"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Second, each kernel allocates LDS variables independent of other kernels and</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00082" /><CodeLine lineNumber="82"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// writes the addresses it chose for each variable into an array in consistent</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00083" /><CodeLine lineNumber="83"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// order. If the kernel does not allocate a given variable, it writes undef to</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00084" /><CodeLine lineNumber="84"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// the corresponding array location. These arrays are written to a constant</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00085" /><CodeLine lineNumber="85"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// table in the order matching the kernel unique integer identifier.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00086" /><CodeLine lineNumber="86"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Third, uses from non-kernel functions are replaced with a table lookup using</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00087" /><CodeLine lineNumber="87"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// the intrinsic function to find the address of the variable.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00088" /><CodeLine lineNumber="88"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00089" /><CodeLine lineNumber="89"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// &quot;Kernel&quot; lowering is only applicable for variables that are unambiguously</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00090" /><CodeLine lineNumber="90"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// reachable from exactly one kernel. For those cases, accesses to the variable</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00091" /><CodeLine lineNumber="91"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// can be lowered to ConstantExpr address of a struct instance specific to that</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00092" /><CodeLine lineNumber="92"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// one kernel. This is zero cost in space and in compute. It will raise a fatal</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00093" /><CodeLine lineNumber="93"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// error on any variable that might be reachable from multiple kernels and is</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00094" /><CodeLine lineNumber="94"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// thus most easily used as part of the hybrid lowering strategy.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00095" /><CodeLine lineNumber="95"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00096" /><CodeLine lineNumber="96"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Hybrid lowering is a mixture of the above. It uses the zero cost kernel</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00097" /><CodeLine lineNumber="97"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// lowering where it can. It lowers the variable accessed by the greatest</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00098" /><CodeLine lineNumber="98"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// number of kernels using the module strategy as that is free for the first</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00099" /><CodeLine lineNumber="99"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// variable. Any futher variables that can be lowered with the module strategy</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00100" /><CodeLine lineNumber="100"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// without incurring LDS memory overhead are. The remaining ones are lowered</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00101" /><CodeLine lineNumber="101"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// via table.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00102" /><CodeLine lineNumber="102"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00103" /><CodeLine lineNumber="103"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Consequences</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00104" /><CodeLine lineNumber="104"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// - No heuristics or user controlled magic numbers, hybrid is the right choice</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00105" /><CodeLine lineNumber="105"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// - Kernels that don&#39;t use functions (or have had them all inlined) are not</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00106" /><CodeLine lineNumber="106"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//   affected by any lowering for kernels that do.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00107" /><CodeLine lineNumber="107"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// - Kernels that don&#39;t make indirect function calls are not affected by those</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00108" /><CodeLine lineNumber="108"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//   that do.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00109" /><CodeLine lineNumber="109"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// - Variables which are used by lots of kernels, e.g. those injected by a</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00110" /><CodeLine lineNumber="110"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//   language runtime in most kernels, are expected to have no overhead</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00111" /><CodeLine lineNumber="111"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// - Implementations that instantiate templates per-kernel where those templates</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00112" /><CodeLine lineNumber="112"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//   use LDS are expected to hit the &quot;Kernel&quot; lowering strategy</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00113" /><CodeLine lineNumber="113"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// - The runtime properties impose a cost in compiler implementation complexity</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00114" /><CodeLine lineNumber="114"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00115" /><CodeLine lineNumber="115"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Dynamic LDS implementation</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00116" /><CodeLine lineNumber="116"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Dynamic LDS is lowered similarly to the &quot;table&quot; strategy above and uses the</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00117" /><CodeLine lineNumber="117"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// same intrinsic to identify which kernel is at the root of the dynamic call</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00118" /><CodeLine lineNumber="118"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// graph. This relies on the specified behaviour that all dynamic LDS variables</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00119" /><CodeLine lineNumber="119"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// alias one another, i.e. are at the same address, with respect to a given</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00120" /><CodeLine lineNumber="120"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// kernel. Therefore this pass creates new dynamic LDS variables for each kernel</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00121" /><CodeLine lineNumber="121"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// that allocates any dynamic LDS and builds a table of addresses out of those.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00122" /><CodeLine lineNumber="122"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// The AMDGPUPromoteAlloca pass skips kernels that use dynamic LDS.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00123" /><CodeLine lineNumber="123"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// The corresponding optimisation for &quot;kernel&quot; lowering where the table lookup</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00124" /><CodeLine lineNumber="124"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// is elided is not implemented.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00125" /><CodeLine lineNumber="125"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00126" /><CodeLine lineNumber="126"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00127" /><CodeLine lineNumber="127"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Implementation notes / limitations</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00128" /><CodeLine lineNumber="128"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// A single LDS global variable represents an instance per kernel that can reach</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00129" /><CodeLine lineNumber="129"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// said variables. This pass essentially specialises said variables per kernel.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00130" /><CodeLine lineNumber="130"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Handling ConstantExpr during the pass complicated this significantly so now</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00131" /><CodeLine lineNumber="131"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// all ConstantExpr uses of LDS variables are expanded to instructions. This</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00132" /><CodeLine lineNumber="132"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// may need amending when implementing non-undef initialisers.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00133" /><CodeLine lineNumber="133"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00134" /><CodeLine lineNumber="134"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Lowering is split between this IR pass and the back end. This pass chooses</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00135" /><CodeLine lineNumber="135"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// where given variables should be allocated and marks them with metadata,</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00136" /><CodeLine lineNumber="136"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// MD&#95;absolute&#95;symbol. The backend places the variables in coincidentally the</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00137" /><CodeLine lineNumber="137"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// same location and raises a fatal error if something has gone awry. This works</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00138" /><CodeLine lineNumber="138"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// in practice because the only pass between this one and the backend that</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00139" /><CodeLine lineNumber="139"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// changes LDS is PromoteAlloca and the changes it makes do not conflict.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00140" /><CodeLine lineNumber="140"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00141" /><CodeLine lineNumber="141"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Addresses are written to constant global arrays based on the same metadata.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00142" /><CodeLine lineNumber="142"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00143" /><CodeLine lineNumber="143"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// The backend lowers LDS variables in the order of traversal of the function.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00144" /><CodeLine lineNumber="144"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// This is at odds with the deterministic layout required. The workaround is to</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00145" /><CodeLine lineNumber="145"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// allocate the fixed-address variables immediately upon starting the function</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00146" /><CodeLine lineNumber="146"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// where they can be placed as intended. This requires a means of mapping from</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00147" /><CodeLine lineNumber="147"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// the function to the variables that it allocates. For the module scope lds,</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00148" /><CodeLine lineNumber="148"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// this is via metadata indicating whether the variable is not required. If a</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00149" /><CodeLine lineNumber="149"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// pass deletes that metadata, a fatal error on disagreement with the absolute</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00150" /><CodeLine lineNumber="150"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// symbol metadata will occur. For kernel scope and dynamic, this is by &#95;name&#95;</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00151" /><CodeLine lineNumber="151"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// correspondence between the function and the variable. It requires the</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00152" /><CodeLine lineNumber="152"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// kernel to have a name (which is only a limitation for tests in practice) and</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00153" /><CodeLine lineNumber="153"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// for nothing to rename the corresponding symbols. This is a hazard if the pass</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00154" /><CodeLine lineNumber="154"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// is run multiple times during debugging. Alternative schemes considered all</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00155" /><CodeLine lineNumber="155"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// involve bespoke metadata.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00156" /><CodeLine lineNumber="156"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00157" /><CodeLine lineNumber="157"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// If the name correspondence can be replaced, multiple distinct kernels that</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00158" /><CodeLine lineNumber="158"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// have the same memory layout can map to the same kernel id (as the address</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00159" /><CodeLine lineNumber="159"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// itself is handled by the absolute symbol metadata) and that will allow more</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00160" /><CodeLine lineNumber="160"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// uses of the &quot;kernel&quot; style faster lowering and reduce the size of the lookup</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00161" /><CodeLine lineNumber="161"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// tables.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00162" /><CodeLine lineNumber="162"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00163" /><CodeLine lineNumber="163"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// There is a test that checks this does not fire for a graphics shader. This</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00164" /><CodeLine lineNumber="164"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// lowering is expected to work for graphics if the isKernel test is changed.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00165" /><CodeLine lineNumber="165"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00166" /><CodeLine lineNumber="166"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// The current markUsedByKernel is sufficient for PromoteAlloca but is elided</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00167" /><CodeLine lineNumber="167"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// before codegen. Replacing this with an equivalent intrinsic which lasts until</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00168" /><CodeLine lineNumber="168"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// shortly after the machine function lowering of LDS would help break the name</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00169" /><CodeLine lineNumber="169"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// mapping. The other part needed is probably to amend PromoteAlloca to embed</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00170" /><CodeLine lineNumber="170"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// the LDS variables it creates in the same struct created here. That avoids the</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00171" /><CodeLine lineNumber="171"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// current hazard where a PromoteAlloca LDS variable might be allocated before</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00172" /><CodeLine lineNumber="172"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// the kernel scope (and thus error on the address check). Given a new invariant</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00173" /><CodeLine lineNumber="173"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// that no LDS variables exist outside of the structs managed here, and an</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00174" /><CodeLine lineNumber="174"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// intrinsic that lasts until after the LDS frame lowering, it should be</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00175" /><CodeLine lineNumber="175"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// possible to drop the name mapping and fold equivalent memory layouts.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00176" /><CodeLine lineNumber="176"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00177" /><CodeLine lineNumber="177"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//===----------------------------------------------------------------------===//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00178" /><CodeLine lineNumber="178"></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00179" /><CodeLine lineNumber="179"><span class="doxyHighlightPreprocessor">#include &quot;<a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/amdgpu/amdgpu-h">AMDGPU.h</a>&quot;</span></CodeLine>

<Link id="l00226" /><CodeLine lineNumber="226"><span class="doxyHighlight">    </span><span class="doxyHighlightStringLiteral">&quot;amdgpu-lower-module-lds-strategy&quot;</span><span class="doxyHighlight">,</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00227" /><CodeLine lineNumber="227"><span class="doxyHighlight">    <a href="/docs/api/structs/llvm/cl/desc">cl::desc</a>(</span><span class="doxyHighlightStringLiteral">&quot;Specify lowering strategy for function LDS access:&quot;</span><span class="doxyHighlight">), <a href="/docs/api/namespaces/llvm/cl/#a68075925a54790e71ca790e1d4f21a40a263ac008d8d31f13ce460395fc4cf7e6">cl::Hidden</a>,</span></CodeLine>

<Link id="l00264" /><CodeLine lineNumber="264"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightKeyword">static</span><span class="doxyHighlight"> </span><span class="doxyHighlightKeywordType">void</span><span class="doxyHighlight"> markUsedByKernel(<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/function">Function</a> &#42;Func, <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/globalvariable">GlobalVariable</a> &#42;SGV) &#123;</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00265" /><CodeLine lineNumber="265"><span class="doxyHighlight">    </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// The llvm.amdgcn.module.lds instance is implicitly used by all kernels</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00266" /><CodeLine lineNumber="266"><span class="doxyHighlight">    </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// that might call a function which accesses a field within it. This is</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00267" /><CodeLine lineNumber="267"><span class="doxyHighlight">    </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// presently approximated to &#39;all kernels&#39; if there are any such functions</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00268" /><CodeLine lineNumber="268"><span class="doxyHighlight">    </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// in the module. This implicit use is redefined as an explicit use here so</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00269" /><CodeLine lineNumber="269"><span class="doxyHighlight">    </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// that later passes, specifically PromoteAlloca, account for the required</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00270" /><CodeLine lineNumber="270"><span class="doxyHighlight">    </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// memory without any knowledge of this transform.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00271" /><CodeLine lineNumber="271"></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00272" /><CodeLine lineNumber="272"><span class="doxyHighlight">    </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// An operand bundle on llvm.donothing works because the call instruction</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00273" /><CodeLine lineNumber="273"><span class="doxyHighlight">    </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// survives until after the last pass that needs to account for LDS. It is</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00274" /><CodeLine lineNumber="274"><span class="doxyHighlight">    </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// better than inline asm as the latter survives until the end of codegen. A</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00275" /><CodeLine lineNumber="275"><span class="doxyHighlight">    </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// totally robust solution would be a function with the same semantics as</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00276" /><CodeLine lineNumber="276"><span class="doxyHighlight">    </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// llvm.donothing that takes a pointer to the instance and is lowered to a</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00277" /><CodeLine lineNumber="277"><span class="doxyHighlight">    </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// no-op after LDS is allocated, but that is not presently necessary.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00278" /><CodeLine lineNumber="278"></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00279" /><CodeLine lineNumber="279"><span class="doxyHighlight">    </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// This intrinsic is eliminated shortly before instruction selection. It</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00280" /><CodeLine lineNumber="280"><span class="doxyHighlight">    </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// does not suffice to indicate to ISel that a given global which is not</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00281" /><CodeLine lineNumber="281"><span class="doxyHighlight">    </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// immediately used by the kernel must still be allocated by it. An</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00282" /><CodeLine lineNumber="282"><span class="doxyHighlight">    </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// equivalent target specific intrinsic which lasts until immediately after</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00283" /><CodeLine lineNumber="283"><span class="doxyHighlight">    </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// codegen would suffice for that, but one would still need to ensure that</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00284" /><CodeLine lineNumber="284"><span class="doxyHighlight">    </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// the variables are allocated in the anticipated order.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00285" /><CodeLine lineNumber="285"><span class="doxyHighlight">    <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/basicblock">BasicBlock</a> &#42;Entry = &amp;Func-&gt;getEntryBlock();</span></CodeLine>

<Link id="l00778" /><CodeLine lineNumber="778"><span class="doxyHighlight">      </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// The association between kernel function and LDS struct is done by</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00779" /><CodeLine lineNumber="779"><span class="doxyHighlight">      </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// symbol name, which only works if the function in question has a</span></CodeLine>

<Link id="l00819" /><CodeLine lineNumber="819"><span class="doxyHighlight">    </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Create a dynamic lds variable with a name associated with the passed</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00820" /><CodeLine lineNumber="820"><span class="doxyHighlight">    </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// function that has the maximum alignment of any dynamic lds variable</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00821" /><CodeLine lineNumber="821"><span class="doxyHighlight">    </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// reachable from this kernel. Dynamic LDS is allocated after the static LDS</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00822" /><CodeLine lineNumber="822"><span class="doxyHighlight">    </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// allocation, possibly after alignment padding. The representative variable</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00823" /><CodeLine lineNumber="823"><span class="doxyHighlight">    </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// created here has the maximum alignment of any other dynamic variable</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00824" /><CodeLine lineNumber="824"><span class="doxyHighlight">    </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// reachable by that kernel. All dynamic LDS variables are allocated at the</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00825" /><CodeLine lineNumber="825"><span class="doxyHighlight">    </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// same address in each kernel in order to provide the documented aliasing</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00826" /><CodeLine lineNumber="826"><span class="doxyHighlight">    </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// semantics. Setting the alignment here allows this IR pass to accurately</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00827" /><CodeLine lineNumber="827"><span class="doxyHighlight">    </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// predict the exact constant at which it will be allocated.</span></CodeLine>
